course.description: Urban and regional planning issues from a geographical perspective. Definition of community and its spatial expression in contemporary urban settings, institutional urban planning legislation, history of Canadian planning practice, contemporary urban and community planning practices, relationships between interests of community stakeholders and municipal decision-making process. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of GEOG 128, GEOG 129 and third-year standing.

course.title: Geography of Housing
course.description: Topics focused on the Canadian city, including current housing markets, neighbourhood change, market failures and housing problems, social housing, and the role of government and policy. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of GEOG 128, GEOG 129 and third-year standing.

course.title: Population Geography
course.description: The relationship between population growth, demographic changes, urbanization, and the environment. Demographic patterns, mortality, fertility and state policy, economic development, migration and immigration, planning, and policy issues. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of GEOG 128, GEOG 129 and third-year standing.

course.title: Soil Science
course.description: Physical, chemical, and biological properties of soils, soil formation and classification. Soil physics and water movement. Soil productivity, conservation, and sustainability. The application of soil science to land use, environmental quality, global change, and sustainable development. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 466 or EESC 456. [3-3-0]
course.prerequisite: One of EESC 111, EESC 200, GEOG 109, CHEM 111, CHEM 121, PHYS 111, PHYS 112. Third-year standing.

course.title: Cartography and Society
course.description: A study of the art, science, politics, and application of maps and map-making. Lectures contain a core social-theory component that explores the critical cartography discourse - the creation of maps to address issues of location, representation, and power. Seminars will debate contemporary issues in cartography. [2-0-1]
course.prerequisite: All of GEOG 128, GEOG 129, GEOG 272 and third-year standing.

course.title: Qualitative Research in Human Geography
course.description: Theoretical aspects, principles, and methods of qualitative research in human geography. [1-0-2]

course.title: Advanced Seminar in Critical Geography
course.description: Surveys a range of approaches to critical theory in human geography. Topics include theoretical approaches to understanding geographies of everyday life: feminism, postcolonialism, postmodernism, poststructuralism, and socialism. [0-0-3]
course.prerequisite: All of GEOG 128, GEOG 129 and third-year standing.

course.title: Selected Topics in Geography
course.description: Intensive examination of a selected geographical theme or region. Contact the Department for more information. With different topics, the course can be taken more than once for credit.

course.title: Directed Studies in Geography
course.description: Students will undertake a supervised investigation which will result in a written report of the findings. The topic will be agreed upon by the supervising faculty member, the student, and the department head.
course.prerequisite: Third-year standing, and permission of the relevant unit head and the supervising faculty member.

course.title: Survey of the Ancient World
course.description: Survey of ancient history from the first civilizations in the Near East to the fall of Rome. Includes examinations of the ancient civilizations of Mesopotamia, Egypt, Greece, and Rome. This course is intended as a basis for understanding the origins of Western civilization. [3-0-0]

course.title: Modern United States History
course.description: Survey of the major economic, political, and social developments from the Civil War to the present. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 111 or HIST 221. [3-0-0]

course.title: Canada to 1867
course.description: Contributions of the First Nations, French, English, and others to the social, economic, and political development of Canada. Also offered by distance education. [3-0-0]

course.title: World History from First to Second World War
course.description: Study of the emergence of the contemporary world from the origins of World War I to the aftermath of World War II. [3-0-0]

course.title: History of Western Civilization,1450-1789
course.description: Survey of the major events, systems of thought, and human accomplishments that have contributed to Western civilization. Study includes events dating from approximately 1450, when developments in government, science, industry, art, and philosophy began to accelerate significantly. [3-0-0]

course.title: Medieval Europe
course.description: Introduction to the changes in European society from the late Roman Empire to the Renaissance, with an emphasis on the Middle Ages as a dynamic era. The period saw the development of many of the institutions of modern civilization, including common law, parliament, and the university. Religion, family, and warfare in the Middle Ages are examined. [3-0-0]

course.title: Canada Since 1867
course.description: Analysis of the social, economic, and political development of the Canadian nation since Confederation. Also offered by distance education. [3-0-0]

course.title: History of Western Civilization, 1789 to Present
course.description: Survey of the development of Europe through the political, social, and industrial revolutions that ushered in the age of European supremacy. Examination of the World Wars and their impact on the decline of Europe. [3-0-0]

course.title: Contemporary World History
course.description: Events and forces shaping the world since the mid-twentieth century. [3-0-0]

course.title: Modern Latin American History
course.description: Survey of the major economic, political, and social currents in Latin America from independence to the present. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 151 or HIST 241. [3-0-0]

course.title: Religion in the West
course.description: History of Western religious traditions from the first civilizations to the present. Origins of and development in Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: One of HIST 110, HIST 116, HIST 119, HIST 126.

course.title: The United States to 1865
course.description: Study of themes of the major economic, political, and social developments in what would become the United States from the late fifteenth century through the Civil War. [3-0-0]

course.title: Introduction to the History of Modern China, 1800 to Present
course.description: Overview of the economic, social, political, and intellectual dynamics of the modern history of China. The history of China from the Chinese perspective and the impact of the West and modernization on that history. [3-0-0]

course.title: Technology in History
course.description: Introduction to the history of technology and society from antiquity to the present. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 3 credits of HIST, or MDST 101 and 3 credits of COSC.

course.title: History of Science
course.description: Survey of important events in the history of science from ancient times to the present. [3-0-0]

course.title: Introduction to the History of Modern Japan and Korea, 1800 to Present
course.description: Introduction to the most important economic, social, political, and cultural forces that have shaped the modern development of Japan and Korea. [3-0-0]

course.title: History of the Canadian Prairies to 1890
course.description: Prairie history including native societies, European fur trade, Metis, Rupert's Land's entry into Confederation, National Policy, and the political evolution of Manitoba and the North West Territories to 1890. [3-0-0]

course.title: History of the Canadian Prairies Since 1890
course.description: The Prairies from the turn-of-the-century migration boom, the new transcontinental railways, the wheat economy, the new provinces, the Progressives and the Wheat Pool, the Depression, the decline of rural society, and rise of postwar resource economies. [3-0-0]

course.title: Pre-Contact and Colonial Latin American History
course.description: Study of themes of Latin American history from emergence of indigenous civilizations to the end of Spanish and Portuguese colonialism in the nineteenth century. [3-0-0]

course.title: History of Indigenous Peoples of Canada to 1876
course.description: The Indigenous people (status and non-status) of Canada from contact to the passage of the Indian Act in 1876. Topics include government policies, environment, gender, religion, oral narratives, colonial frontiers, disease, fur trade. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 300 or HIST 302. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST and third-year standing; or HIST 112, INDG 100, and third-year standing.

course.title: History of Indigenous Peoples of Canada Since 1876
course.description: The Indigenous people (status and non-status) of Canada from the passage of the Indian Act in 1876 to the present. Topics include government policies, environment, gender, religion, oral narratives, activism, urbanization, identity. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 301 or HIST 302. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST and third-year standing; or HIST 112, INDG 100, and third-year standing.

course.title: British Imperial History up to 1783
course.description: Examines the rationales and criticisms of empire; mercantilism, industrial capitalism, and free trade; methods and systems that gave rise to the British Empire and the factors which explain the fall of the first British Empire. [2-0-1]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 116 and third-year standing.

course.title: French North America to 1803
course.description: Historical background for understanding the French-speaking peoples of North America: Acadians, Franco-Qu?b?cois, French-Canadians, and Cajuns. Deals extensively with French-Amerindian relations. Introduction to the historiography of French North America. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 112, HIST 211 and third-year standing.

course.title: The Scientific Revolution
course.description: Study of the history of the natural sciences in early modern time. Science transformed from natural philosophy to technology; theories of nature and human nature; science and objectivity; the social role of the scientist; the intellectual authority of science. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 218 and third-year standing.

course.title: The Rise of Modern Science
course.description: Study of the history of the natural sciences since the scientific revolution. This course may be taken separately or as a continuation of HIST 308. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 218 and third-year standing.

course.title: Topics in the History of Medicine and Disease
course.prerequisite: Either one of (a) HIST 218 and third-year standing, or (b) 6 credits of HIST.

course.title: British Imperial History, 1783-1950
course.description: Examines colonial policies and practices of imperial Britain in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries; the role of explorers, traders, missionaries, industrialists, and others in the growth of British imperialism; the emergence of organized colonial resistance and the decolonization movement; independence and the new Commonwealth of Nations. [2-0-1]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 115, HIST 126, HIST 145 and third-year standing.

course.title: Women in Canada and the US to 1867
course.description: History of women and women's experiences in Canada and the United States from European contact to the latter half of the nineteenth century. Women's experiences in the broader context of political, social, and economic events and changes. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 112, HIST 211 and third-year standing.

course.title: History of Southern Africa
course.description: Pre-colonial, colonial, and contemporary history emphasizing South Africa. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 115, HIST 145 and third-year standing.

course.title: Women in Canada and the US from 1867 to the Present
course.description: History of women and women's experiences in Canada and the United States from the late 1800s to the present. Women's experiences in the broader context of political, social, and economic events and changes. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 112, HIST 211 and third-year standing.

course.title: Europe in 1215
course.description: Examines aspects of the Middle Ages such as popular religion, the feudal system, and courtly love, and the appearance of Parliament, common law, and the university. Focuses on the eventful year 1215. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 119 and third-year standing.

course.title: The British North American Colonies, 1749-1873
course.description: Comparative study of the British North American colonies that became provinces of the Dominion of Canada. Regional distinctions as well as shared characteristics in the light of literature, folklore, social structure, art, architecture, and politics. [3-0-0]

course.title: American Colonial History, 1607-1763
course.description: Comparative study of the social, economic, and political characteristics of the 13 colonies as they changed from small European outposts to more mature societies. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 211 and third-year standing.

course.title: The American Revolution and the Formation of the United States
course.description: Study of the revolutionary origins of the United States of America and the establishment of the American republic. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 211 and third-year standing.

course.title: Canadian Social History
course.description: Study of selected topics in the history of Canadian society including frontier settlement, rural life, religion, social and institutional structures, immigration and ethnicity, social movements, ideology, family life and life cycles, demographic change, labour, industrialization, and urbanization. [3-0-0]

course.title: The United States, 1812-1865
course.description: Political development in the new American nation, with special emphasis on expansion, regionalism, Jacksonian democracy, social reform, and the Civil War. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 211 and third-year standing.

course.title: The United States, 1865-1896
course.description: Political and social development in Post-Civil War America with special emphasis on Reconstruction, industrialization, and the Gilded Age. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 211 and third-year standing.

course.title: Europe in the 19th Century
course.description: Investigation of main themes in European history from the French Revolution to the beginning of the twentieth century. Domestic politics, the interaction of states, the formation of new states, social and economic transformations affecting the whole civilization, major cultural expressions of the century. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 126 and third-year standing.

course.title: Eastern Europe During the Cold War
course.description: A political, social, and cultural history of Eastern Europe from the end of the Second World War to the fall of state socialism. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: Either (a) one of HIST 115, HIST 126 and third-year standing or (b) 6 credits of HIST.

course.title: Tudor England, 1485-1603
course.description: Study of the political, religious, and social changes in England from the late Middle Ages to the early seventeenth century. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 116, HIST 119 and third-year standing.

course.title: Stuart England, 1603-1714
course.description: Study of the changes in politics, economics, and the empire from James I to Queen Anne and Robert Walpole. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 116 and third-year standing.

course.title: History of Gender and Sexuality in Latin America
course.description: Role of gender and sexuality from colonial period to the present. Role of the family and community in reinforcing sexual and gendered roles. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 151, HIST 240, HIST 241 and third-year standing.

course.title: Class and Culture in Latin America
course.description: Relationship between culture and class formation from the late-colonial period to the present. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 151, HIST 240, HIST 241, CULT 101 and third-year standing.

course.title: Foundations of Modernity in 19th-Century Latin American History
course.description: Intellectual underpinnings of early nation-state development and social groups which consolidated control between 1820 and 1914, and the political systems developed. Confronts divergent constructions and experiences of modernity across the region. Focus mainly on Argentina, Brazil, Mexico. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 151, HIST 240, HIST 241, CULT 101.

course.title: Social Movements in 20th-Century Latin America
course.description: Social movements of Latin America since 1900 that have challenged the status quo. Role of ideology, culture, and identity in the struggles of marginalized peoples. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 151, HIST 240, HIST 241 and third-year standing.

course.title: Digital Archives, Cultural Heritage, and Public History
course.description: Interdisciplinary introduction to digital archiving, exhibition, and preservation of cultural heritage and public history. Deals with collective memory, politics of commemoration and collecting, and future of digital collection and museum interfaces. [3-0-0]

course.title: Special Topics in Economic History
course.description: Students should consult the department for the particular topics offered in a given year. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 9 credits of HIST and third-year standing.

course.title: Special Topics in Political History
course.description: Students should consult the department for the particular topics offered in a given year. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 9 credits of HIST and third-year standing.

course.title: Special Topics in Social and Cultural History
course.description: Students should consult the department for the particular topics offered in a given year. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 9 credits of HIST and third-year standing.

course.title: History of India, 1800-1914
course.description: Examines developments of Indian society and culture under the British Raj during the period of 1800-1914, the consolidation of British power in nineteenth-century India, and early Indian resistance to imperial rule. [2-0-1]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 115 and third-year standing.

course.title: History of India Since 1914
course.description: Examines the origins and growth of the freedom struggle in India, the emergence of independent states in the subcontinent, and the problems of nation building and modernization since 1947. [2-0-1]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 115, HIST 145 and third-year standing.

course.title: The Spanish and Austrian Habsburgs to 1700
course.description: Influence of the Hapsburg dynasty on the history of Europe from 16th to 17th centuries. Expansion into two branches of the family in Spain and Central Europe, Austria. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 116, HIST 119, HIST 240 and third-year standing.

course.title: Problems in International Relations: Diplomacy and the Origins of Wars
course.description: Study of the relationship of the diplomatic factor to other factors in the origins of the First and Second World Wars. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 115, HIST 126 and third-year standing.

course.title: British Columbia to 1900
course.description: Topics from the history of colonial British Columbia, Confederation, and subsequent provincial developments during the nineteenth century. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 406 or HIST 404. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST and third-year standing; or HIST 112 and third-year standing.

course.title: British Columbia Since 1900
course.description: Topics will emphasize changes in the economic, social, and institutional structures of the province during the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 407 or HIST 404. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST and third-year standing; or HIST 122 and third-year standing.

course.title: History of the Habsburg Monarchy
course.description: Examination of the growth and development of the monarchy with emphasis on the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. Some discussion of the successor states after 1918. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 116, HIST 126 and third-year standing.

course.title: Russia in the 19th Century
course.description: The various forces that shaped Russia's domestic and foreign policy in the nineteenth century, beginning with the challenges presented by the Napoleonic Wars. A major focus will be Westernization and the emergence of the Russian revolutionary movement. [3-0-0]

course.title: History of Russia, 800-1796
course.description: Examines the social, economic, and political history of Russia during the Kievan, Muscovite, and eighteenth-century Imperial period. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 110, HIST 116, HIST 119 and third-year standing.

course.title: Topics in the History of International Relations
course.description: Special topics such as the role of diplomacy and its relation to other factors in international affairs, Canadian external relations, third-world international politics, Cold-War historiography, and area studies. [3-0-0]

course.title: Reformation Europe
course.description: Examination of European history, 1450-1650, that places both the Protestant Reformation and the Catholic Reformation in the broader context of the political, social, cultural, and economic changes during the early modern era. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 116, HIST 119 and third-year standing.

course.title: Medieval England
course.description: Study of selected themes in the history of England from the eleventh to the fifteenth centuries. [1.5-0-1.5]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 119 and third-year standing.

course.title: Women in Early Modern Europe
course.description: Examination of the experiences of women in Western Europe from 1500-1750. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 116 and third-year standing.

course.title: Women in the Middle Ages
course.description: Examination of women's experiences in Western Europe from about 900-1450. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 119 and third-year standing.

course.title: Topics in the History of Migration
20th-Century Russia, 1900-1939
course.description: Examines the economic, social, and political causes of the collapse of the Russian empire in 1917, the Bolshevik efforts to transform society in the initial years following the Russian Revolution, and the Stalin Revolution of the 1930s. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 115, HIST 126 and third-year standing.

course.title: History of Russian Women and Society, 800-1881
course.description: Focuses on social history and the changing role of women in Russian society and the state. Analyzes women's roles from 800-1881. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 116, HIST 126 and third-year standing.

course.title: Women and Society in 20th-Century Russia, 1881 to Present
course.description: Russian women's movement at the end of the nineteenth century. Early Soviet efforts to alter women's positions/roles by incorporating women's mobilization into larger development strategy. Subordination of women's roles to larger regime priorities, from Stalin Revolution to the end of the Soviet Union and the present. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 126 and third-year standing.

course.title: 20th-Century Russia, 1939 to Present
course.description: Examines the significance of the Great Patriotic War; the last years of Stalin, the tempering of Stalinism in the Khrushchev years; Gorbachev's failed revolution; the collapse of the Soviet Union; and Russia in transition. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 126, HIST 145 and third-year standing.

course.title: Slave Societies in the Americas
course.description: Comparative analysis of the institution of chattel slavery, its growth, its effects on slaves and masters, its relation to the larger society, and the causes of its decline in the various cultures of the Americas. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 211, HIST 240 and third-year standing.

course.title: Selected Topics in Latin American History
course.description: Examination of a major theme in Latin American history such as Spanish-Indian contact, church-state relations, struggles for land and social justice, revolutions, and gender relations. OUC equivalent: HIST 450. [3-0-0]

course.title: History of Mexico Since 1810
course.description: Mexican history since independence including church-state relations, struggles for land and social justice, state formation, class and gender relations, and the role of popular culture. OUC equivalent: HIST 452. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 151, HIST 240, HIST 241 and third-year standing.

course.title: History of Brazil Since 1822
course.description: Post-colonial history of Brazil with special attention to the politics of culture in state-building. OUC equivalent: HIST 453. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 151, HIST 240, HIST 241 and third-year standing.

course.title: The City in Latin America
course.description: History of development of major cities in Latin America from pre-European contact to present. Urban planning, industrialization, municipal politics, shifting demographics, globalization, culture, and class relations. [0-0-3]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 151, HIST 240, HIST 241 and third-year standing.

course.title: Topics in Technology and Society in History
course.description: Historical dimensions of current debates about technology, focusing on a single, interdisciplinary theme. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 215 and third-year standing.

course.title: Topics in Urban History
course.prerequisite: Either (a) HIST 126 and third-year standing or (b) 6 credits of HIST.

course.title: War and Society Prior to 18th Century
course.description: Continuity and change in the relations of war and society, and the connections between the economy, society, the military, and government in peacetime and war; not a course in military history. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 110, HIST 116, HIST 119 and third-year standing.

course.title: Canada, 1896 to World War II
course.description: Survey of the political, social, and economic developments that have shaped Canada from the election of Laurier to World War II. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST including HIST 122; or HIST 122 and third-year standing.

course.title: Canada, World War II to Present
course.description: Survey of the political, social, and economic developments that have shaped Canada from World War II to the present. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST including HIST 122; or HIST 122 and third-year standing.

course.title: International Relations of the Great Powers of the 20th Century to 1939
course.description: International relations of Britain, France, Germany, Russia, and the United States from the beginning of the 20th century until 1939. Political and diplomatic settlements between the Paris Peace Conference of 1919 and the German invasion of Poland in 1939. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 115, HIST 126 and third-year standing; or 6 credits of POLI and third-year standing.

course.title: International Relations of the Great Powers of the 20th Century from 1939
course.description: International relations of Britain, France, Germany, Russia, and the United States since 1939. Emphasis upon the emergence, course, and end of the Cold War. Great Powers in decolonization and the end of empires. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 145, HIST 126 and third-year standing.

course.title: History of Germany to 1789
course.description: Examination of the political, social, and intellectual history of Germanic peoples to 1789. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 116, HIST 119 and third-year standing.

course.title: History of Germany Since 1789
course.description: Examination of the political, social, and intellectual history of the modern Germanies since 1789. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or HIST 126 and third-year standing.

course.title: War and Society from the 18th to 20th Centuries
course.description: Continuity and change in the relations of war and society, and the connections between the economy, society, the military, and government in peacetime and war; not a course in military history. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 115, HIST 116, HIST 126, HIST 145 and third-year standing.

course.title: Directed Studies: Research
course.description: Students will undertake supervised investigation of an assigned topic in history. They will investigate a research problem that involves the generation of original data and present that data in an acceptable format. [0-0-3]
course.prerequisite: Fourth-year standing, 6 credits of upper-level HIST, and permission of the instructor. A minimum of 72% in all completed upper-level HIST courses is required.

course.title: Directed Studies: Readings
course.description: Students will undertake supervised investigation of an assigned topic in history. They will complete a significant amount of independent reading and analysis and produce a major term paper at the end of the course. [0-0-3]
course.prerequisite: Fourth-year standing, 6 credits of upper-level HIST, and permission of the instructor. A minimum of 72% in all completed upper-level HIST courses is required.

course.title: History, Theory, and Method
course.description: Explores selected problems and issues in the theory and practice of historical work.Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 492 or IGS 592. [2-0-1]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST or third-year standing. Open to non-history majors with permission of the department head.

course.title: Decolonization and Africa
course.description: Overview and analysis of the internal and external factors that explain decolonization in sub-Saharan Africa in the twentieth century. Discussion will focus on the problems of nation-building in the aftermath of decolonization. [1.5-0-1.5]
course.prerequisite: 6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 115, HIST 145 and third-year standing.

course.title: Special Topics in History
course.description: Examination of selected topics and issues in history. With different topics, this course may be taken more than once for credit. [3-0-0]

course.title: Digital Media and History
course.description: An introduction to digital media history and the application of digital methods to historical inquiry, interpretation, and communication. [3-3-0]

course.title: Undergraduate Honours Thesis
course.description: Research and writing of a thesis paper under the supervision of a History faculty member. Participation in scheduled colloquia and seminars is required. Restricted to students in the Honours Program (third-year standing; minimum 12 credits of History; minimum grade average of 76% in all attempted History courses; and minimum overall average of 72%).

course.title: Making Predictions with Data
course.description: Introduction to the techniques and software for handling real-world data. Topics include data cleaning, visualization, simulation, basic modeling, and prediction making. [3-1-0]

course.title: Introduction to Data Analytics
course.description: Techniques for computation, analysis, and visualization of data using software. Manipulation of small and large data sets. Automation using scripting. Real-world applications from life sciences, physical sciences, economics, engineering, or psychology. No prior computing background is required. Credit will be granted for only one of COSC 301, DATA 301 or DATA 501. [3-2-0]
course.prerequisite: Either (a) third-year standing, or (b) one of COSC 111 or COSC 122

course.title: Machine Learning
course.description: Regression, classification, resampling, model selection and validation, fundamental properties of matrices, dimension reduction, tree-based methods, unsupervised learning. Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 311 or DATA 311. [3-2-0]
course.prerequisite: Either (a) STAT 230 or (b) a score more than 75% in one of APSC 254, BIOL 202, PSYO 373; and one of COSC 111, APSC 177.

course.title: Modelling and Simulation
course.description: Numeric dynamic systems models and emphasis on discrete stochastic systems. State description of models, common model components, entities. Common simulation language. Simulation using algebraic languages. Simulation methodology: data collection, model design, output analysis, optimization, validation. Elements of queuing theory, relationship to simulation. Applications tocomputer systems models. Credit will be granted for only one of COSC 405, DATA 405, COSC 505, or DATA 505. [3-2-0]
course.prerequisite: A score of 60% or higher in COSC 221 and a score of 60% or higher in COSC 222.

course.title: Sampling and Design
course.description: Planning/practice of data collection. Pros/cons of both observational and experimental data. Survey samples: random sampling; bias and variance; unequal probability sampling; systematic, multistage, and stratified sampling; ratio and regression estimators. Experimental design: simple one-way comparisons; designs with randomization restrictions including blocking, split-plots, nested and repeated measures designs. Credit will be granted for only one of DATA 407, STAT 405, STAT 407, or STAT 507. [3-1-0]
course.prerequisite: One of STAT 230, PSYO 372, BIOL 202, ECON 327.

course.title: Regression and Generalized Linear Models
course.description: Regression, linear models, generalized linear models, additive models, generalized additive models, mixed models. Theory and numerical performance. Credit will be granted for only one of DATA 410, STAT 310, STAT 410, or STAT 538. [3-2-0]

course.title: Topics in Data Science
course.description: Advanced or specialized topics in data science. Consult the department for the specific topic to be offered in any given year. This course may be taken more than once for credit with different topics. [3-2-0]

course.title: Network Science
course.description: Graphs and complex networks in scientific research. Probabilistic and statistical models. Structures, patterns, and behaviors in networks. Algorithmic and statistical methods. (online/mobile) social networks and social media platforms. Social influence, information diffusion, and viral marketing. Sentiment analysis and opinion mining. Data privacy. Search engines and recommendation systems. Credit will be granted for only one of COSC 421, DATA 421 or DATA 521. [3-2-0]

course.title: Directed Studies in Data Science
course.description: Investigation of a specific topic as agreed upon by the student and the faculty supervisor. Completion of a project and an oral presentation are required.
course.prerequisite: Third-year standing in the Data Science major or Honours, and permission of the department head.

course.title: Honours Thesis
course.description: Students will undertake a research project as agreed upon by the student, supervising faculty member, and unit head. A written thesis and a public presentation (poster or seminar) are required. Restricted to students in the B.Sc. Data Science Honours Program.
course.prerequisite: Fourth-year standing and permission of the department head.

course.title: Communication and Consulting in Data Science
course.description: Effective consulting practices, ethical considerations, methodology selection, data preparation, effective software development. Credit will be granted for only one of DATA 500 or STAT 400 when the subject matter is of the same nature.

course.title: Data Analytics
course.description: Techniques for computation, analysis, and visualization of data using software. Manipulation of small and large data sets. Automation using scripting. Real-world applications from life sciences, physical sciences, engineering, or psychology. Credit will be granted for only one of COSC 301, DATA 301 or DATA 501.

course.title: Modelling and Simulation
course.description: Simulation methodology: data collection, model design, output analysis, optimization, validation. Credit will be granted for only one of COSC 405, DATA 405, COSC 505, or DATA 505.

course.title: Network Science
course.description: Graphs and complex networks in scientific research. Probabilistic and statistical models. Structures, patterns, and behaviors in networks. Algorithmic and statistical methods. (online/mobile) social networks and social media platforms. Social influence, information diffusion, and viral marketing. Sentiment analysis and opinion mining. Data privacy. Search engines and recommendation systems. Credit will be granted for only one of COSC 421, DATA 421 or DATA 521.

course.title: Computing Platforms for Data Science
course.description: Introduction to software and tools for Data Science. Setup process. Credit will be granted for only one of DATA 301 or DATA 530. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Programming for Data Science
course.description: Programming including decisions, loops, functions, and using data structures and libraries. Credit will be granted for only one of DATA 301 or DATA 531. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Algorithms and Data Structure
course.description: Data structures including lists, queues, stacks, hash tables, trees and graphs. Recursion. Searching and sorting. Asymptotic complexity. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Collaborative Software Development
course.description: Software life cycle. Licensing. Packaging. Testing and quality control. Version control. Collaborative environments.

course.title: Web and Cloud Computing
course.description: Parallel and cloud computing architectures and program deployment. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Databases and Data Retrieval
course.description: Using and querying relational and NoSQL databases for analysis. Experience with SQL, JSON, and programs that use databases. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Scripting and Reporting
course.description: Scripting engines for data science. Reporting tools. Automation. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Data Wrangling
course.description: Manipulation of data using software tools. Data conversion, filtering, sorting, grouping, cleaning, parsing. Automation. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Data Collection
course.description: Fundamental techniques in the collection of data. Focus will be devoted to understanding the effects of randomization, restrictions on randomization, repeated measures and blocking on the model fitting. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Dataviz I
course.description: Data visualization to produce graphs and images. Advanced data analysis on spreadsheets. Credit will be granted for only one of DATA 301 or DATA 550. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Dataviz II
course.description: Data visualization using business intelligence and data analysis software. Interactive visualization. Production of visualizations for mobile and web. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Communication and Argumentation
course.description: Interpretation of data. Argumentation: hypothesis, claim, evidence and inference. Model limitations: bias, validity, reliability, sensitive analysis. Communication of recommendations to decision-makers. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Privacy, Security and Professional Ethics
course.description: Data privacy laws and expectations. Freedom of information. Ethics board. Licensing. Data security. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Predictive Modelling
course.description: Introduction to regression for Data Science. Simple linear regression, multiple linear regression, interactions, mixed variable types, model assessment, simple variable selection, k-nearest-neighbours regression. Credit will be granted for only one of DATA 311 or DATA 570. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Resampling and Regularization
course.description: Resampling techniques and regularization for linear models. Bootstrap, jackknife, cross-validation, ridge regression, lasso, discussion of tuning parameters. Credit will be granted for only one of DATA 311 or DATA 571. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Supervised Learning
course.description: Analysis of data with categorical responses. Logistic regression, k-nearest-neighbours classification, discriminant analysis, decision trees and random forests. Credit will be granted for only one of DATA 311 or DATA 572. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Unsupervised and Semi-supervised Learning
course.description: Analyses for data with unknown responses. Distance measures, hierarchical clustering, k-means, mixture models. Restrict

course.title: Modelling and Simulation I
course.description: Pseudorandom number generation, testing and transformation to other discrete and continuous data types. Introduction to Poisson processes and the simulation of data from predictive models, as well as temporal and spatial models. Credit will be granted for only one of DATA 405 or DATA 583. Restricted to students in the MDS program.
course.prerequisite: Either (a) all of STAT 230, DATA 301 or (b) all of DATA 570, DATA 530.

course.title: Modelling and Simulation II
course.description: Markov chains and their applications, for example, queueing and Markov Chain Monte Carlo. Credit will be granted for only one of DATA 405 or DATA 581. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Bayesian Inference
course.description: Introduction to Bayesian paradigm and tools for Data Science. Topics include Bayes theorem, prior, likelihood and posterior. A detailed analysis of the cases of binomial, normal samples, normal linear regression models. A significant focus will be on computational aspects of Bayesian problems using software packages. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Advanced Predictive Modelling
course.description: Multiple linear regressions. Splines. Smoothing. Generalized additive models. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Optimization
course.description: Modeling using mathematical programming. Fundamental continuous and discrete optimization algorithms. Optimization software for small to medium scale problems. Optimization algorithms for data science. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Advanced Machine Learning
course.description: Neural networks, backpropagation, deep learning. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Special Topic
course.description: Advanced or specialized topic in Data Science with applications to specific data sets. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Capstone
course.description: A capstone design project designed to give students experience in performing data science on a complex multidisciplinary project. Restricted to students in the MDS program.

course.title: Contemporary Educational Issues
course.description: Seminar that examines special topics and current issues within education. Pass/Fail. [1-0-0]

course.title: Contemporary Educational Practice
course.description: Seminar that explores various approaches, projects, methodologies, and teaching applications. Pass/Fail. [1-0-0]

course.title: Studies in Educational Leadership
course.description: Seminar that investigates effective educational programs, leadership, and practice. Pass/Fail. [1-0-0]

course.title: Conceptions of Teaching and Learning
course.description: Examines the philosophical foundations of teaching and learning in local/global contexts. Emphasis is on pedagogical knowledge relating to teaching, learning, and learner differences, and how educators can work productively in relation to curriculum, assessment and instructional media.

course.title: Conceptualizing Educational Technology
course.description: Provides an overview of educational technology bridging theory and practice. Educational technology is conceptualized broadly as the study and ethical practice of facilitating learning and improving performance by creating, using and managing appropriate technological processes and resources.

course.title: Designing Instruction
course.description: Introduces instructional design from analysis through evaluation and implementation. Emphasizes contemporary issues of designing instruction for diverse settings and contexts.

course.title: Leading and Managing Educational Technology Innovation
course.description: Exploring the leadership issues that emerge as new technologies increasingly influence educational contexts. Leadership models and the administrative concerns of program implementation and resource/project management are examined. Staff development, security, and policies for ethical use are explored.

course.title: Educational Technology and Converging Media
course.description: Examination of the role of information technologies and communications media in current and future educational systems. Particular attention will be given to issues involved in innovation and change in education, and to converging computer-mediated communications: computer, television, and telephony.

course.title: Instructional Strategies for Digital Learning
course.description: Advanced topics in instructional design and project management.

course.title: Creating Technology-Enhanced Learning Environments
course.description: Paradigm shifts in education have influenced significant change in learning environments. This course is an inquiry into learning environments (past, present, and future) and explores the learning theories, software, hardware, and instructional strategies that support them.

course.title: Introduction to Decolonization: Indigenous Studies
course.description: Provides students with an overview of the discipline of Indigenous studies including the history, cultures, and experiences of Indigenous people. [2-0-1]

course.title: Introduction to Indigeneity: Ways of Knowing
course.description: Introduces students to the concept of Indigenous Knowledge through a holistic and relational approach to land and people. Provides a foundation to key perspectives and traditions in the arts, health, social justice and governance. [3-0-0]

course.title: Okanagan Indigenous Peoples' Historical Perspectives
course.description: Indigenous historiography as demonstrated through Okanagan traditional oral techniques for documentation of knowledge; an indigenous peoples' approach to orality and the maintenance of social, ecological, and land-based practice. Offered in relationship with the En'owkin Centre. [3-0-0]

course.title: Okanagan Concepts and Frameworks
course.description: Indigenous perspectives as demonstrated through Okanagan theory and practice; a systems-based indigenous peoples' approach to landscape and ecology. Offered in relationship with the En'owkin Centre. [3-0-0]

course.title: Indigenous Peoples' Historical Perspectives
course.description: Overview of the historical and contemporary socio-economic, political, cultural, and ecological perspectives of indigenous peoples. [3-0-0]

course.title: Indigenous Peoples of the Americas
course.description: Overview of the contemporary socio-economic, political, cultural, and environmental characteristics of the Indigenous peoples of the Americas. [3-0-0]

course.title: Indigenous Studies: Special Topics
course.description: An examination of selected topics in Indigenous studies. Consult the program brochure for this year's offerings and specific prerequisites. Credit will be granted for only one of INDG 295 or INDG 395.

course.title: Examining an Indigenous Methodology: En'owkinwixw
course.description: Understanding an indigenous strategy of community discourse as a methodology for inquiry, a technique of examination employing sequential stages of critical analysis in a whole-systems approach. Offered in relationship with the En'owkin Centre. [3-0-0]

course.title: Indigenous Governance
course.description: Critically examines various traditional Indigenous governance models and the Indigenous response to European attempts to establish political control. Issues such as land ownership, sovereignty, justice, treaty making, and the roles of women in Indigenous governance will be explored. [3-0-0]

course.title: Indigenous Studies Theory and Methodology
course.description: Conceptualizations from an Indigenous perspective are central to this course. Includes an analysis of current conceptual paradigms within the social sciences, humanities, and performing arts, with a consideration of their appropriateness and applicability for Indigenous studies. [3-0-0]

course.title: Indigenous Studies Field Methods
course.description: Research strategies and research techniques used in Indigenous studies and related disciplines. These elements will be applied to various topical issues including intellectual property rights, research ethics, oral histories, ethnographic research, and the use of statistics (both descriptive and inferential). [3-0-0]

course.title: Indigenous Justice
course.description: Decolonial Indigenous concepts, principles and historical consciousness of justice and anti-violence praxis in community-and-land based contexts. Locating agency with Indigenous peoples and Indigenous justice practices, the course puts primacy on ways that Indigenous peoples have engaged in and continue to enact justice. Revitalization of Indigenous knowledge informs ethical and moral issues addressed in relation to healing, and collective transformation. [3-0-0]

course.title: Indigenous Land Rights
course.description: Legal theories under British Law or its historical derivations that have been used to justify the colonization of Indigenous peoples. Legal arguments and anthropological evidence raised by Indigenous groups to challenge those theories. Particular reference is paid to Canada, Australia, New Zealand, and the United States. [3-0-0]

course.title: Traditional Ecological Knowledge
course.description: Shows how human life depends on complex systems of cultural knowledge about the natural world. Indigenous people's biological classification and nomenclatural systems, ethnobiology, and Indigenous explanatory models of environmental systems and the application of this knowledge in practice. [3-0-0]

course.title: Indigenous Culture, Heritage, and Intellectual Property
course.description: Indigenous Peoples' cultural heritage in the Americas and other continents. Many manifestations of Indigenous cultures will be discussed, as well as the many complex issues that have arisen regarding Indigenous heritage in the colonial and neo-colonial periods such as, customary laws, misappropriation, misrepresentation, repatriation, and legal protection and regulation. [3-0-0]

course.title: Indigenous Perspectives on Health
course.description: Introduction to current thinking about Indigenous peoples' health, and especially Indigenous peoples' perspectives on health and contemporary health systems. Includes a critical examination of concepts of health within the context of ongoing processes of colonization. [3-0-0]

course.title: Indigenous Women's Perspectives: Gender, Nation, State, Resistance
course.description: Historical realities of the salience of states and nations in the lives of Indigenous women. Indigenous methods, de-colonial historical analysis, and gender theory are used to analyze Indigenous women's and peoples' resistances to invasion, colonization, occupation, settler states, and dispossession. [3-0-0]

course.title: Research Applications
course.description: The planning of research projects from the perspective of Indigenous cultures and values. Topics include project development, community relations and ethics, and identification and acquisition of appropriate resources. [0-0-3]

course.title: Indigenous Peoples United Nations and Global Issues
course.description: Focuses on Indigenous Peoples' common experience of colonialism, non-recognition, conflicts with nation states, and decolonization. Also covers Indigenous Peoples' international engagement and lobbying in various UN forums, including The UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples. [3-0-0]

course.title: Indigenous Education: History and Revitalization
course.description: Indigenous perspectives on language and cultural shifts through the critical lenses of Indigenous knowledge and insider views on historical education policies; language and knowledge loss and consequences; revitalization and recovery; and transformational community development through Indigenous education and community empowerment. [3-0-0]

course.title: Indigenous Perspectives on Food, Place, Identity, and Biodiversity
course.description: Overview of the contemporary geopolitical, agricultural, and environmental connections between identity, food, place, and cultural and biological diversity from the perspective of Indigenous peoples. North/south flows of genetic resources and key international and regional conventions and agreements are highlighted. [3-0-0]

course.title: Residential Schools and Reconciliation
course.description: The history of the Indian Residential School (IRS) is placed within the context of colonization and the official Canadian Government policy of assimilation. The IRS legacy will be placed in the context of issues confronted by the Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada. [3-0-0]

course.title: Indigenous Women, Activisms, Feminisms
course.description: Examines Indigenous womens feminist activisms and theory in historical and contemporary contexts. Emphasizing resistance against colonization, dispossession, violence and ecological destruction as well as development of strategies and models based on Indigenous concepts and consciousness. Emphasizes relationship building and empowerment between Indigenous women beyond borders. [0-0-3]

course.title: Directed Studies: Readings in Indigenous Studies
course.description: Supervised investigation of an assigned topic in Indigenous studies. Independent reading and analysis, and a major term paper. Normally, students may take INDG 481 only once for credit.
course.prerequisite: INDG 100. 3 credits in INDG 200- or 300-level courses, permission of the unit head and third-year standing.

course.title: Advanced Topics in Indigenous Studies
course.description: With permission of the program advisor, students may take and receive credit for this course more than once. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: INDG 100. 3 credits in INDG 200- or 300-level courses, and third-year standing.

course.title: Nursing Lab Practice I
course.description: Develops evidence-informed nursing practice through seminar, laboratory learning, and simulation. Students gain knowledge, skills, and abilities needed to practice foundational nursing assessments and safe ethical care. Weekly concepts will align with NRSG 136 intentional learning activities. [0-1.5-3]
course.prerequisite: All of NRSG 111, NRSG 112, NRSG 113, BIOL 131.

course.title: Foundations of Health
course.description: Meaning of health and healing. Recognize diversity of beliefs, values, and perceptions of health. Introduction to the Canadian Health Care System, conceptual frameworks of health promotion, determinants of health, disease and injury prevention, and primary health care. [3-0-0]

course.title: Introduction to the Profession of Nursing I
course.description: Critical reflection of the historical, political, and socioeconomic evolution of nursing. Exploration of foundational theories, nursing practice standards, ethical principles, ethical decision making, and health law that guides evidence-informed professional nursing practice. [1.5-0-0]

course.title: Relational Practice I
course.description: Understanding of self and the capacity to be in caring relation with others (individual, groups, populations, communities). Reflecting on personal perspectives and experiences to understand ones own attitudes, beliefs, and values. Pass/Fail [1.5-0-0]

course.title: Introduction to Nursing Research
course.description: Introduction to nursing research to provide knowledge, skills, and abilities to engage in evidence-informed nursing practice. Key topics will include research concepts, approaches, procedures/processes, ethics, and application in diverse health care settings. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of HINT 110, NRSG 111, NRSG 112 and English (3 credits)
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 101, NRSG 122, NRSG 123, NRSG 126, NRSG 136.

course.title: Introduction to the Profession of Nursing II
course.description: Explores the historical development of nursing knowledge, theory, contemporary understandings of nursing as a discipline, the current body of knowledge defining it, and the relationship between practice and theory. Development of teaching and learning knowledge, skills, and abilities. [1.5-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of HINT 110, NRSG 111, NRSG 112, NRSG 113, BIOL 131.

course.title: Relational Practice II
course.description: Understanding relational care and relational ethics to build knowledge, skills, and abilities to engage in relational practice with diverse individuals, families, and groups. Explore concepts and evidence for caring, therapeutic communication, and relational identity. Pass/Fail. [1.5-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of HINT 110, NRSG 111, NRSG 112, NRSG 113, BIOL 131.
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 101, NRSG 120, NRSG 122, NRSG 126, NRSG 136.

course.title: Health & Healing I
course.description: Introduction to adult health assessment with a focus on the older adult with stable chronic health conditions. Concepts will align with NRSG 136 intentional learning activities. Nursing theories and evidence-informed frameworks guide approaches to care, assessments, clinical reasoning, and care planning. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of HINT 110, NRSG 111, NRSG 112, NRSG 113, BIOL 131.
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 101, NRSG 120, NRSG 122, NRSG 123, NRSG 136.

course.title: Nursing Practice I
course.description: This first nursing practicum develops knowledge, skills, and abilities to provide safe ethical nursing care to adults with stable chronic health challenges. Intentional learning activities integrate knowledge from NRSG 101 and NRSG 126. The focus is on assessment, clinical reasoning, care planning, and documentation. Pass/Fail. [0-6-0]
course.prerequisite: All of HINT 110, NRSG 111, NRSG 112, NRSG 113, BIOL 131.
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 101, NRSG 120, NRSG 122, NRSG 123, NRSG 126.

course.title: L.P.N. Access to B.S.N
course.description: For students entering the Bachelor of Science in Nursing (B.S.N.) Access program. Participants will be introduced, through theory and simulated learning activities, to the foundational constructs associated with nursing courses in the first year of the nursing program. [3-0-0]

course.title: Nursing Lab Practice II
course.description: Develops evidence-informed nursing practice through seminar, laboratory learning, and simulation. Students advance knowledge, skills, and abilities in preparation to practice nursing assessments and safe ethical care in acute care settings. Concepts will align with NRSG 236 intentional learning activities. [0-3-1.5]
course.prerequisite: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133 and Second-Year BSN-O Standing
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 210, NRSG 213, NRSG 226, NRSG 236, BIOL 231.

course.title: Nursing Lab Practice III
course.description: This course is a continuation of NRSG 201 and provides additional opportunities to develop evidence-informed approaches for safe ethical care. Concepts will align with NRSG 237 intentional learning activities. [0-3-1.5]
course.prerequisite: All of NRSG 201, NRSG 210, NRSG 213, NRSG 226, NRSG 236, BIOL 231.
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 220, NRSG 223, NRSG 227, NRSG 237, BIOL 235.

course.title: Pharmacology for Nursing I
course.description: Principles of pharmacology, including pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of major drug classes using prototype drugs. Develops knowledge and systematic approaches to safely and ethically administer drug therapy. [1.5-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133 and Second-Year BSN-O Standing
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 201, NRSG 213, NRSG 226, NRSG 236, BIOL 231.

course.title: Relational Practice III
course.description: Emphasis is on the unique experience of clients and their families in health and illness. Through exploration of relational theories and evidence-informed approaches, students explore strategies to deliver therapeutic, ethical, and holistic care. Pass/Fail. [1.5-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133 and Second-Year BSN-O Standing
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 201, NRSG 210, NRSG 226, NRSG 236, BIOL 231.

course.title: Pharmacology for Nursing II
course.description: This course is a continuation of NRSG 210, further expanding on the principles of pharmacology. Further expanding on knowledge and systematic approaches to safely and ethically administer drug therapy. [1.5-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of NRSG 201, NRSG 210, NRSG 213, NRSG 226, NRSG 236, BIOL 231.
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 202, NRSG 223, NRSG 227, NRSG 237, BIOL 235.

course.title: Relational Practice IV
course.description: Evidence-informed strategies and approaches of relational inquiry to build relational skills and capacity. Socio-cultural constructs in relation to health and healing. Pass/Fail. [1.5-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of NRSG 201, NRSG 210, NRSG 213, NRSG 226, NRSG 236, BIOL 231.
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 202, NRSG 220, NRSG 227, NRSG 237, BIOL 235.

course.title: Health & Healing II
course.description: Evidence-informed assessment and management of health challenges in both episodic and chronic illness. Concepts will align with NRSG 236 intentional learning activities. [1.5-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133 and Second-Year BSN-O Standing
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 201, NRSG 210, NRSG 213, NRSG 236, BIOL 231.

course.title: Health & Healing III
course.description: This course is a continuation of NRSG 226, further expanding on evidence-informed assessment and management of health challenges in both episodic and chronic illness. Concepts will align with NRSG 237 intentional learning activities. [1.5-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of NRSG 201, NRSG 210, NRSG 213, NRSG 226, NRSG 236, BIOL 231.
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 202, NRSG 220, NRSG 223, NRSG 237, BIOL 235.

course.title: Community Health
course.description: Theories, ethics and evidence-informed approaches to community health nursing including primary health care, population health, health maintenance and promotion, disease and injury prevention. Exploration of concepts of community- based assessment, planning, intervention and evaluation with community-as-client. [1.5-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133 and Second-Year BSN-O Standing

course.title: Mental Health
course.description: Evidence-informed promotion of mental well-being, assessment and management of episodic and chronic mental health challenges across the life span. Concepts will align with NRSG 239 intentional learning activities. [1.5-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133 and Second-Year BSN-O Standing

course.title: Nursing Practice II
course.description: This practicum in acute care settings develops beginning knowledge, skills, and abilities to provide safe ethical nursing care for adults with episodic and chronic health challenges. Intentional learning activities integrate evidence-informed knowledge from NRSG 201 and NRSG 226. The focus is on assessment, clinical reasoning, care planning, and documentation. Pass/Fail. [0-6-0]
course.prerequisite: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133 and Second-Year BSN-O Standing
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 201, NRSG 210, NRSG 213, NRSG 226, BIOL 231.

course.title: Nursing Practice III
course.description: This second acute care practicum is a continuation of NRSG 236. Develops advancing knowledge, skills, and abilities to provide safe ethical nursing care for adults with episodic and chronic health challenges. Intentional learning activities integrate evidence-informed knowledge from NRSG 202 and NRSG 227. Pass/Fail. [0-6-0]
course.prerequisite: All of NRSG 201, NRSG 210, NRSG 213, NRSG 226, NRSG 236, BIOL 231.
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 202, NRSG 220, NRSG 223, NRSG 227, BIOL 235.

course.title: Nursing Practice in Community
course.description: Practicum in community health nursing develops knowledge, skills, and abilities needed to provide to provide safe ethical nursing care health care within varied community settings with diverse populations. Students will draw on principles of social justice and the social determinants of health to engage in evidenced-informed community assessments, health promotion/illness prevention activities, and health teaching. Pass/Fail. [0-6-0]
course.prerequisite: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133 and Second-Year BSN-O Standing

course.title: Nursing Practice in Mental Health
course.description: Practicum in mental health provides opportunities to acquire knowledge, skills, and attitudes to promote wellness, through safe, ethical nursing care, in a variety of contexts. The focus will be presenting a mental well-being project to a specific target population. Other experiences will provide students an understanding of the mental health nursing process. Intentional learning activities integrate evidence-informed concepts from NRSU 229. Pass/Fail. [0-6-0]
course.prerequisite: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133 and Second-Year BSN-O Standing

course.title: Nursing Lab Practice IV
course.description: Develops evidence-informed nursing practice through seminar, laboratory learning, and simulation. Students advance knowledge, skills, and abilities in preparation to practice safe ethical nursing care in acute medical settings. [0-1.5-2]
course.prerequisite: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133, BIOL 231, BIOL 235. Third-year BSN-O Standing
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 310, NRSG 311, NRSG 326, NRSG 336.

course.title: Nursing Lab Practice V
course.description: Develops evidence-informed nursing practice through seminar, laboratory learning, and simulation. Students advance knowledge, skills, and abilities in preparation to practice safe ethical nursing care in acute surgical settings. [0-1.5-2]
course.prerequisite: All of NRSG 301, NRSG 310, NRSG 311, NRSG 326, NRSG 336, BIOL 131, BIOL 133, BIOL 231, BIOL 235.
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 313, NRSG 320, NRSG 327, NRSG 337.

course.title: Palliative Approach to Chronic Illness
course.description: Examination of the philosophy, principles, and evidence-informed practice of a palliative approach to the care of patient/clients with life-limiting chronic illness over the illness trajectory, including end of life and bereavement. This course will pay special attention to ethics and older adults. [3-0-0]

course.title: Relational Practice V
course.description: Understanding and respecting the complexities of difference and diversity with clients in nursing practice. A critical exploration of cultural identities and racism from an Indigenous perspective, facilitates development of evidence-informed practice for culturally safe care for all peoples in a variety of contexts (health care, research, institutions, and society). Pass/Fail. [3-0-0]

course.title: Global Health
course.description: Explores the role of the nurse within the context of the global society and the changing health care environment. Develops knowledge of emerging health issues and trends, evidence-informed approaches and ethical concerns for nursing practice at the global level. [3-0-0]

course.title: Health & Healing IV
course.description: Evidence-informed assessment and management of complex health challenges in both episodic and chronic illness utilizing a case study approach. [3-0-0 (over 6 weeks)] [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133, BIOL 231, BIOL 235 and Third-year BSN-O Standing.
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 301, NRSG 310, NRSG 311, NRSG 336.

course.title: Health & Healing V
course.description: Continuation of NRSG 326. Evidence-informed assessment and management of complex health challenges in both episodic and chronic illness utilizing a case study approach. [3-0-0 (over 6 weeks)] 3-0-0
course.prerequisite: All of NRSG 301, NRSG 310, NRSG 311, NRSG 326, NRSG 336.
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 302, NRSG 313, NRSG 320, NRSG 337.

course.title: Health of the Childbearing Family
course.description: Nursing within a health promotion framework in both community and acute care settings. Evidence-informed guidelines for care of the childbearing family during pregnancy, labour, birth, and postpartum will be drawn on to inform assessment and management of holistic, ethical care. Concepts will align with NRSG 338 intentional learning activities. [3-0-0 (over 6 weeks)] 3-0-0
course.prerequisite: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133, BIOL 231, BIOL 235 and Third-year BSN-O Standing

course.title: Child Health
course.description: Child health nursing within a health promotion framework in both community and acute care settings. Family-centered care and inter-professional collaboration will be examined with a focus on understanding the diversity and unique needs of both children and families to inform holistic, ethical care. Concepts will align with NRSG 339 intentional learning activities. [3-0-0 (over 6 weeks)] 3-0-0
course.prerequisite: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133, BIOL 231, BIOL 235 and Third-year BSN-O Standing

course.title: Nursing Practice in Medical Settings
course.description: This early immersion practicum develops advanced knowledge, skills, and abilities for evidence-informed patient care with adults experiencing episodic and chronic health challenges. Ethical dilemmas common to this area of practice will be explored within an ethical decision making framework. Pass/Fail. [0-16-0]
course.prerequisite: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133, BIOL 231, BIOL 235 and Third-year BSN-O Standing.
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 301, NRSG 310, NRSG 311, NRSG 326.

course.title: Nursing Practice in Surgical Settings
course.description: This early immersion practicum develops advanced knowledge, skills, and abilities for evidence-informed patient care with adults experiencing episodic and chronic health challenges. Ethical dilemmas common to this area of practice will be explored within an ethical decision-making framework. Pass/Fail. 0-16-0
course.prerequisite: All of NRSG 301, NRSG 310, NRSG 311, NRSG 326, NRSG 336.
course.corequisite: All of NRSG 302, NRSG 313, NRSG 320, NRSG 327.

course.title: Nursing Practice with Childbearing Families
course.description: This specialty practicum develops beginning knowledge, skills, and abilities to provide evidence-informed nursing care in newborn family health contexts. Intentional learning activities integrate knowledge from NRSG 328. Ethical considerations common to this area of practice will be explored. Pass/Fail. 0-8-0
course.prerequisite: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133, BIOL 231, BIOL 235 and Third-year BSN-O Standing

course.title: Nursing Practice in Child Health
course.description: This specialty practicum develops beginning knowledge, skills, and abilities to provide evidence-informed nursing care in a variety child health care contexts. Intentional learning activities integrate knowledge from NRSG 329. Ethical considerations common to this area of practice will be explored. Pass/Fail. 0-8-0
course.prerequisite: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133, BIOL 231, BIOL 235 and Third-year BSN-O Standing

course.title: Health and Healing VI: Global Health Issues
course.description: Emphasis is placed on the role of the nurse within the context of the global society and the changing health care environment. Participants examine a variety of emerging health issues and trends, developing their personal understanding of nursing practice. [3-0-0]

course.title: Capstone Review
course.description: A comprehensive review of entry-level nursing knowledge, skills, and abilities in preparation for writing the nursing entry to practice regulatory examination. Through simulation and interactive case studies participants will have opportunities to apply previous learning and clinical reasoning to situations commonly seen in the first year of registered nursing practice. [3-0-0]

course.title: Leadership
course.description: Nursing leadership at various levels of the healthcare system with an emphasis on leadership, decision-making, and change theories. Consider the impact of trends, issues, and ethics on leadership in nursing. [3-0-0]

course.title: Advanced Clinical Reasoning for Care of the Complex Client
course.description: Theory and research for evidence-informed practice for the assessment and care of the complex, unstable, acutely ill patient. Understanding challenging etiology, pathophysiology, manifestations, diagnostics and intervention to inform advanced clinical reasoning. [3-0-0]

course.title: Nursing Practice VIII: Transitioning to B.S.N. Graduate Part 1
course.description: Opportunity to consolidate learning and prepare for assuming the role of B.S.N. graduate. Area of focus may be a particular setting of practice, client population, or health challenge. Practice is designed in collaboration with faculty. B.S.N. Basic students must complete this course for 6 credits which will require the completion of 268 hours over 7 weeks. R.N. Access students must complete this course for 3 credits which will require the completion of 134 hours. Pass/Fail.
course.prerequisite: All of NRSG 414, NRSG 421, NRSG 422. Students must successfully complete all program requirements prior to enrolling in full-time practicum (R.N. Access students are exempt).

course.title: Advanced Gerontology
course.description: Theory, research, and best practices for ethical care of the older adult and aging populations builds nursing knowledge, skills, and abilities in gerontology. Develops advanced understanding of issues pertaining to the older adult population in acute and community settings. 3-0-0

course.title: Advanced Mental Health
course.description: Theory and research for ethical, evidence-informed practice for mental health nursing. Develops advanced knowledge of the pathophysiology, etiology, manifestations, diagnostics and intervention to inform care of patients experiencing acute mental health challenges. [3-0-0]

course.title: Advanced Community Health Nursing
course.description: Theory, research, and best practices for ethical community health nursing builds knowledge, skills, and abilities for practice with diverse populations in a variety of community settings. Develops advanced understanding of health promotion, disease and injury prevention, population health, and epidemiology. [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: All of NRSG 228, NRSG 238 and Fourth-Year BSN-O Standing

course.title: Advanced Global Health
course.description: Theory, research, and best practices for ethical global health nursing builds knowledge, skills, and abilities for practice. Develops advanced understanding of healthcare systems globally in relation to the determinants of health for diverse populations in cross-cultural and resource-constrained environments. 3-0-0

course.title: Capstone Acute Care Preceptorship
course.description: Preceptored practice course consolidates acute care clinical knowledge, skills, and abilities. Demonstrates evidence-informed practice at a graduate nurse level. Pass/Fail.
course.prerequisite: All of NRSG 421, NRSG 422, NRSG 432 and the recommendation of practice advising committee.

course.title: Capstone Community Project
course.description: This practice course provides opportunity to experience evidenced-informed leadership through application of concepts such as influencing and managing change within the context of emerging global health issues and trends. Pass/Fail. [0-72-24]

course.title: Health Science III
course.description: Participants will pursue an in-depth study of interest arising from nursing practice as it relates to health science and will present a synopsis of their study to the rest of the class. Some topic coordination and lectures will be provided. [3-0-0]
course.corequisite: NRSG 414. NRSG corequisite for this course requires concurrent registration.

course.title: Practice Electives
course.description: Preceptored advanced practice experience(s) provides opportunities for evidence-informed practice in varied contexts*. Application of knowledge, skills, and abilities from related advanced nursing theory course(s). Pass/Fail. *Dependent on availability
course.prerequisite: All of NRSG 421, NRSG 422, NRSG 432. a min of 3 credits of nursing electives related to practicum context, and recommendation of practice advising committee.

course.title: Special Topics in Nursing
course.description: Variable-content elective course dealing with special issues and advanced topics in health and nursing practice. Offered subject to student requests and to professor availability. The course may be taken twice for credit (on different topics). [3-0-0]
course.prerequisite: Third-year standing in the B.S.N. program.

course.title: Gerontology Preceptorship
course.description: Preceptored advanced practice experience(s) provides opportunities for evidence-informed practice with the older adult. Application of knowledge, skills, and abilities from related advanced nursing theory course(s). Opportunity to work with interprofessional teams in a variety of settings*. Pass/Fail. *Dependent on availability
course.prerequisite: All of NRSG 421, NRSG 422, NRSG 426, NRSG 432 and recommendation of practice advising committee.

course.title: Mental Health Preceptorship
course.description: Preceptored advanced practice experience(s) provides opportunities for evidence-informed practice with the client experiencing challenges with mental health. Application of knowledge, skills, and abilities from related advanced nursing theory course(s). Opportunity to work with interprofessional teams in a variety of settings. [4 credits 120 hours over 4 weeks or 8 credits 240 hours over 8 weeks]
course.prerequisite: All of NRSG 421, NRSG 422, NRSG 432, NRSG 427.

course.title: Community Health Nursing Preceptorship
